questions.question: A speed skater crosses the $25\text{ m}$ mark with a speed of $10.5\text{ m/s}$ and the $75\text{ m}$ mark with a speed of $13.2\text{ m/s}$. Assuming constant acceleration, calculate the skater's acceleration.
questions.explanation: Using $v^2 = u^2 + 2a\Delta x$ with $\Delta x = 75 - 25 = 50\text{ m}$: $(13.2)^2 = (10.5)^2 + 2a(50) \rightarrow 174.24 = 110.25 + 100a \rightarrow a = 63.99/100 \approx 0.64\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A freight train traveling at an initial speed of $26\text{ m/s}$ applies its emergency brakes, decelerating uniformly at $0.45\text{ m/s}^2$. Calculate the distance the train travels before coming to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: Using $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$ with $v = 0$: $0 = (26)^2 + 2(-0.45)s \rightarrow s = 676/0.9 \approx 751.1 \approx 750\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A metal bolt is dropped from rest from the top of a skyscraper. If it takes $5.8\text{ s}$ to reach the sidewalk below, calculate the height of the building. Neglect air resistance.
questions.explanation: Using $h = \frac{1}{2}gt^2 = 4.9 \times (5.8)^2 = 4.9 \times 33.64 = 164.8 \approx 160\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A ball is thrown vertically upward and is caught $4.8\text{ s}$ later at the same height it was released. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the maximum height reached by the ball.
questions.explanation: Time to reach maximum height is half the total time: $t = 4.8/2 = 2.4\text{ s}$. Maximum height: $h = \frac{1}{2}gt^2 = 4.9 \times (2.4)^2 = 4.9 \times 5.76 = 28.22 \approx 28\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A pebble is flicked horizontally from a counter that is $1.2\text{ m}$ high and lands $2.8\text{ m}$ from the base of the counter. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the speed at which the pebble left the counter.
questions.explanation: Time of fall: $t = \sqrt{2h/g} = \sqrt{2.4/9.8} = \sqrt{0.2449} = 0.495\text{ s}$. Horizontal speed: $v_x = d/t = 2.8/0.495 \approx 5.66 \approx 5.7\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A cannon fires a shell with an initial speed of $85\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $32^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the horizontal range of the shell.
questions.explanation: Using the range formula: $R = \frac{u^2 \sin(2\theta)}{g} = \frac{(85)^2 \sin(64^{\circ})}{9.8} = \frac{7225 \times 0.8988}{9.8} = \frac{6493}{9.8} \approx 662.5 \approx 660\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A projectile is launched from ground level. If it reaches a peak height of $22\text{ m}$, calculate the vertical component of its initial velocity. Neglect air resistance.
questions.explanation: At maximum height, $v_y = 0$. Using $v_y^2 = u_y^2 - 2gh$: $0 = u_y^2 - 2(9.8)(22) \rightarrow u_y = \sqrt{431.2} \approx 20.77 \approx 21\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A canoeist paddles at a speed of $2.5\text{ m/s}$ in still water. They aim directly across a river that is $80\text{ m}$ wide (perpendicular to the banks). If the river current flows at $1.4\text{ m/s}$, calculate the time it takes to reach the far bank.
questions.explanation: The time to cross depends only on the component of velocity perpendicular to the banks. $t = \text{width}/v_{perpendicular} = 80/2.5 = 32\text{ s}$.

questions.question: Car A moves South at a constant speed of $80\text{ km/h}$. Car B moves North at a constant speed of $105\text{ km/h}$. Calculate the velocity of Car B relative to Car A.
questions.explanation: Let North be positive. Then $v_A = -80\text{ km/h}$, $v_B = +105\text{ km/h}$. Relative velocity: $\vec{v}_{B/A} = \vec{v}_B - \vec{v}_A = 105 - (-80) = 185\text{ km/h}$ (positive, so North).

questions.question: An equipment trunk of mass $35\text{ kg}$ is pushed across a horizontal floor with a horizontal force of $140\text{ N}$. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the trunk and the floor is $0.25$, calculate the acceleration of the trunk.
questions.explanation: Friction force: $f_k = \mu_k mg = 0.25 \times 35 \times 9.8 = 0.25 \times 343 = 85.75\text{ N}$. Net force: $F_{net} = 140 - 85.75 = 54.25\text{ N}$. Acceleration: $a = F_{net}/m = 54.25/35 \approx 1.55 \approx 1.6\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A car of mass $1300\text{ kg}$ has tires that provide a maximum friction force of $9500\text{ N}$. Calculate the minimum distance required for the car to come to a complete stop from an initial speed of $28\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: Maximum deceleration: $a = F/m = 9500/1300 = 7.308\text{ m/s}^2$. Using $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$: $0 = (28)^2 + 2(-7.308)s \rightarrow s = 784/(2 \times 7.308) = 784/14.616 \approx 53.66 \approx 54\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A hockey puck of mass $0.35\text{ kg}$ is given an initial velocity of $15\text{ m/s}$ on a horizontal surface. If it slides $32\text{ m}$ before coming to a stop, calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction between the puck and the surface.
questions.explanation: First find acceleration using $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$: $0 = (15)^2 + 2a(32) \rightarrow a = -225/64 = -3.516\text{ m/s}^2$. The friction force provides this deceleration: $\mu_k mg = m|a|$, so $\mu_k = |a|/g = 3.516/9.8 \approx 0.359 \approx 0.36$.

questions.question: An $8.0\text{ kg}$ block slides down an incline making an angle of $25^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. If the kinetic friction force acting on the block is $12\text{ N}$, calculate the block's acceleration.
questions.explanation: Component of weight down the incline: $F_\parallel = mg\sin\theta = 8 \times 9.8 \times \sin25^{\circ} = 78.4 \times 0.4226 = 33.12\text{ N}$. Net force down incline: $F_{net} = 33.12 - 12 = 21.12\text{ N}$. Acceleration: $a = F_{net}/m = 21.12/8.0 = 2.64 \approx 2.6\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the normal force acting on a $15\text{ kg}$ mass that is resting on an incline making an angle of $40^{\circ}$ with the horizontal.
questions.explanation: $N = mg\cos\theta = 15 \times 9.8 \times \cos40^{\circ} = 147 \times 0.7660 \approx 112.6 \approx 110\text{ N}$.

questions.question: Two masses, $5.5\text{ kg}$ and $3.5\text{ kg}$, are connected by a light string over a frictionless, massless pulley in an Atwood machine. Calculate the tension in the string during motion.
questions.explanation: First find acceleration: $a = g\frac{m_2 - m_1}{m_1 + m_2} = 9.8 \times \frac{5.5 - 3.5}{9} = 9.8 \times \frac{2}{9} = 9.8 \times 0.2222 = 2.178\text{ m/s}^2$. Then tension (using the smaller mass): $T = m_2(g + a) = 3.5(9.8 + 2.178) = 3.5 \times 11.978 \approx 41.92 \approx 42\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $12\text{ kg}$ block on a horizontal frictionless table is connected by a light string over a frictionless pulley to an $8.0\text{ kg}$ hanging mass. Starting from rest, calculate the distance the system moves in $1.5\text{ s}$.
questions.explanation: Acceleration: $a = \frac{m_2g}{m_1 + m_2} = \frac{8 \times 9.8}{20} = 78.4/20 = 3.92\text{ m/s}^2$. Distance: $s = \frac{1}{2}at^2 = 0.5 \times 3.92 \times (1.5)^2 = 1.96 \times 2.25 = 4.41 \approx 4.4\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A hanging plant of mass $2.4\text{ kg}$ is supported by two wires that make an angle of $40^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Calculate the tension in each wire.
questions.explanation: Vertical equilibrium: $2T\cos40^{\circ} = mg = 2.4 \times 9.8 = 23.52\text{ N}$. Thus $T = 23.52/(2 \times 0.7660) = 23.52/1.532 \approx 15.35 \approx 15\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $70\text{ kg}$ person is in an elevator. If the tension in the elevator cable is $820\text{ N}$, calculate the magnitude and direction of the elevator's acceleration.
questions.explanation: Weight: $mg = 70 \times 9.8 = 686\text{ N}$. Since tension ($820\text{ N}$) is greater than weight, acceleration is upward. From $T - mg = ma$: $820 - 686 = 70a \rightarrow 134 = 70a \rightarrow a = 134/70 \approx 1.914 \approx 1.9\text{ m/s}^2$ upward.

questions.question: A washing machine drum has a radius of $0.28\text{ m}$ and spins at $800\text{ rpm}$ (revolutions per minute). Calculate the centripetal acceleration of a point on the inner wall of the drum.
questions.explanation: Angular velocity: $\omega = 800 \times \frac{2\pi}{60} = 800 \times 0.10472 = 83.78\text{ rad/s}$. Centripetal acceleration: $a_c = r\omega^2 = 0.28 \times (83.78)^2 = 0.28 \times 7018 \approx 1965 \approx 2.0 \times 10^3\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: An object moves in a circle of radius $3.5\text{ m}$ with a constant tangential speed of $14\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the frequency of the motion.
questions.explanation: Frequency: $f = \frac{v}{2\pi r} = \frac{14}{2\pi \times 3.5} = \frac{14}{21.99} \approx 0.637 \approx 0.64\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: A $0.20\text{ kg}$ ball is attached to a string of length $0.70\text{ m}$ and whirled in a vertical circle. At the bottom of the loop, its speed is $6.5\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the tension in the string at that point.
A car of mass $1400\text{ kg}$ passes over the crest of a circular hump with a radius of $35\text{ m}$. Calculate the speed at which the car will just lose contact with the road at the crest.
questions.explanation: At the point of losing contact, the normal force is zero and gravity alone provides the centripetal force: $mg = \frac{mv^2}{R} \rightarrow v = \sqrt{gR} = \sqrt{9.8 \times 35} = \sqrt{343} \approx 18.52 \approx 19\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $1100\text{ kg}$ car travels around a flat, unbanked curve of radius $55\text{ m}$ at a constant speed of $18\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the centripetal force acting on the car.
A $0.40\text{ kg}$ ball is swung in a horizontal circle by a string of length $1.5\text{ m}$. If the tension in the string is $25\text{ N}$, calculate the tangential speed of the ball.
questions.explanation: For horizontal circular motion, tension provides the centripetal force: $T = \frac{mv^2}{r} \rightarrow v = \sqrt{\frac{Tr}{m}} = \sqrt{\frac{25 \times 1.5}{0.40}} = \sqrt{93.75} \approx 9.68 \approx 9.7\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Calculate the gravitational force between a $75\text{ kg}$ astronaut and a $12000\text{ kg}$ satellite when their centers are $10\text{ m}$ apart. Use $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\text{ NÂ·m}^2/\text{kg}^2$.
A planet has twice the radius of Earth and three times the mass of Earth. Calculate the acceleration due to gravity on its surface. (Take $g_{Earth} = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.)
questions.explanation: $g_p = G\frac{3M_E}{(2R_E)^2} = \frac{3}{4} \times G\frac{M_E}{R_E^2} = 0.75 \times 9.8 = 7.35 \approx 7.4\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $15\text{ kg}$ box is pulled a distance of $12\text{ m}$ across a floor at a constant speed. If the pulling force is $45\text{ N}$, calculate the work done by the friction force on the box.
questions.explanation: Since the box moves at constant speed, the pulling force equals the friction force in magnitude. Thus $f_k = 45\text{ N}$. Work done by friction: $W = -f_k d = -45 \times 12 = -540\text{ J}$.

questions.question: Calculate the work required to increase the speed of a $2200\text{ kg}$ truck from $12\text{ m/s}$ to $24\text{ m/s}$.
A $0.15\text{ kg}$ ball traveling at $25\text{ m/s}$ is caught by a glove that moves back $0.12\text{ m}$ while stopping the ball. Calculate the average force exerted by the glove on the ball.
questions.explanation: Initial kinetic energy: $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5 \times 0.15 \times 625 = 0.075 \times 625 = 46.875\text{ J}$. This energy is dissipated as work done by the glove: $W = Fd \rightarrow F = W/d = 46.875/0.12 \approx 390.6 \approx 390\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $0.60\text{ kg}$ ball is thrown from the top of a $15\text{ m}$ high bridge with an initial speed of $12\text{ m/s}$. If it hits the water below with a speed of $16\text{ m/s}$, calculate the amount of energy lost to air resistance during the fall.
questions.explanation: Initial total energy: $E_i = mgh + \frac{1}{2}mv_i^2 = 0.6 \times 9.8 \times 15 + 0.5 \times 0.6 \times 144 = 88.2 + 43.2 = 131.4\text{ J}$. Final kinetic energy: $E_f = \frac{1}{2}mv_f^2 = 0.5 \times 0.6 \times 256 = 0.3 \times 256 = 76.8\text{ J}$. Energy lost: $131.4 - 76.8 = 54.6 \approx 55\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $3.0\text{ kg}$ block is compressed against a horizontal spring with spring constant $k = 800\text{ N/m}$ by a distance of $0.15\text{ m}$ and then released. Assuming no friction, calculate the speed of the block after it has passed through the equilibrium position (where the spring is unstretched).
questions.explanation: Conservation of energy: $\frac{1}{2}kx^2 = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \rightarrow v = \sqrt{\frac{kx^2}{m}} = \sqrt{\frac{800 \times (0.15)^2}{3.0}} = \sqrt{\frac{800 \times 0.0225}{3.0}} = \sqrt{6} \approx 2.45 \approx 2.5\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $1.5\text{ kW}$ electric heater is operated for $15\text{ minutes}$. Calculate the total energy consumed in Joules.
questions.explanation: Time in seconds: $t = 15 \times 60 = 900\text{ s}$. Energy: $E = Pt = 1500 \times 900 = 1,350,000 = 1.35 \times 10^6 \approx 1.4 \times 10^6\text{ J}$.

questions.question: How much power is required to lift a $65\text{ kg}$ person a vertical height of $4.0\text{ m}$ in $2.5\text{ s}$?
questions.explanation: Work done: $W = mgh = 65 \times 9.8 \times 4.0 = 65 \times 39.2 = 2548\text{ J}$. Power: $P = W/t = 2548/2.5 \approx 1019 \approx 1.0 \times 10^3\text{ W}$.

questions.question: Calculate the work required to stretch a spring with spring constant $k = 250\text{ N/m}$ from its equilibrium position to a stretch of $0.22\text{ m}$.
A spring stores $8.0\text{ J}$ of elastic potential energy when it is compressed by $0.12\text{ m}$. Calculate the spring constant.

A car of mass $1500\text{ kg}$ moving East at $12\text{ m/s}$ collides head-on with a stationary truck of mass $2500\text{ kg}$. If they lock together after the collision, calculate their final velocity.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $1500 \times 12 = (1500 + 2500)v \rightarrow 18000 = 4000v \rightarrow v = 18000/4000 = 4.5\text{ m/s East}$.

questions.question: Two identical billiard balls have an elastic collision. Ball 1 moves at $3.5\text{ m/s}$ North and hits Ball 2, which is at rest. What is the velocity of Ball 1 after the collision?
questions.explanation: In a perfectly elastic collision between equal masses where one is initially at rest, the velocities are exchanged. Therefore, Ball 1 comes to rest ($0\text{ m/s}$) and Ball 2 moves with Ball 1's initial velocity.

questions.question: A $2.5\text{ kg}$ object initially at rest explodes into two pieces. One piece has a mass of $1.0\text{ kg}$ and moves West at $18\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the velocity of the other piece.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $0 = m_1v_1 + m_2v_2$. Taking West as negative: $0 = 1.0(-18) + (2.5 - 1.0)v_2 = -18 + 1.5v_2 \rightarrow 1.5v_2 = 18 \rightarrow v_2 = 18/1.5 = 12\text{ m/s}$. The positive sign indicates East.

questions.question: A $12\Omega$ resistor and a $24\Omega$ resistor are connected in series with a $12\text{ V}$ battery. Calculate the voltage drop across the $24\Omega$ resistor.
questions.explanation: Using the voltage divider formula: $V_{24} = V \times \frac{R_2}{R_1 + R_2} = 12 \times \frac{24}{12 + 24} = 12 \times \frac{24}{36} = 12 \times \frac{2}{3} = 8.0\text{ V}$.

questions.question: Two resistors are connected in series and have a total resistance of $150\Omega$. If one resistor is $60\Omega$, calculate the ratio of the power dissipated by the two resistors.
questions.explanation: The other resistor has resistance $R_2 = 150 - 60 = 90\Omega$. In a series circuit, the current is the same through both resistors, so power is proportional to resistance: $P_1:P_2 = R_1:R_2 = 60:90 = 2:3$.

questions.question: Calculate the equivalent resistance of resistors with values $20\Omega$, $40\Omega$, and $40\Omega$ connected in parallel.
A $36\text{ V}$ battery is connected to two $18\Omega$ resistors wired in parallel. Calculate the total current leaving the battery.
questions.explanation: For two equal resistors in parallel, $R_{eq} = R/2 = 18/2 = 9\Omega$. Total current: $I = V/R_{eq} = 36/9 = 4.0\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A $10\Omega$ resistor is connected in series with a parallel combination of two $20\Omega$ resistors. Calculate the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The two $20\Omega$ resistors in parallel give $R_p = 20/2 = 10\Omega$. Adding the series $10\Omega$ resistor: $R_{total} = 10 + 10 = 20\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the current through a $15\Omega$ resistor that is connected in series with a parallel combination of a $10\Omega$ and a $40\Omega$ resistor. The entire circuit is powered by a $24\text{ V}$ source.
questions.explanation: The parallel combination gives $R_p = \frac{10 \times 40}{10 + 40} = \frac{400}{50} = 8\Omega$. Total resistance: $R_{total} = 15 + 8 = 23\Omega$. Total current (which flows through the $15\Omega$ series resistor) is $I = V/R_{total} = 24/23 \approx 1.043 \approx 1.0\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A wave on a string has a frequency of $120\text{ Hz}$ and a speed of $30\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the wavelength.
questions.explanation: Using the wave equation: $\lambda = v/f = 30/120 = 0.25\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A $2.5\text{ m}$ long string has a total mass of $20\text{ g}$ and is under a tension of $80\text{ N}$. Calculate the speed of waves on this string.
questions.explanation: Linear mass density: $\mu = m/L = 0.020/2.5 = 0.008\text{ kg/m}$. Wave speed: $v = \sqrt{T/\mu} = \sqrt{80/0.008} = \sqrt{10000} = 100\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $440\text{ Hz}$ tuning fork moves toward a stationary wall at $12\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the frequency of the sound reflected back to the source. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: This is a double Doppler effect. First, the wall acts as a stationary observer hearing frequency $f' = f_0 \frac{v}{v - v_s} = 440 \times \frac{340}{340 - 12} = 440 \times \frac{340}{328} = 440 \times 1.0366 = 456.1\text{ Hz}$. Then the wall acts as a source emitting this frequency toward the moving source (which is now moving toward the wall). The frequency heard back at the source is $f'' = f' \frac{v + v_s}{v} = 456.1 \times \frac{340 + 12}{340} = 456.1 \times \frac{352}{340} = 456.1 \times 1.0353 \approx 472.2 \approx 470\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Two speakers emit sound in phase. Destructive interference occurs at a point where the path difference from the speakers is $0.60\text{ m}$. Calculate the lowest possible frequency of the sound. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For destructive interference with in-phase sources, the condition is $\Delta x = (n + \frac{1}{2})\lambda$. For the lowest frequency (longest wavelength), take $n = 0$, giving $0.60 = \lambda/2 \rightarrow \lambda = 1.2\text{ m}$. Then $f = v/\lambda = 340/1.2 \approx 283.3 \approx 280\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Calculate the frequency of the second harmonic for a pipe that is $0.85\text{ m}$ long and open at both ends. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For an open pipe, the harmonic frequencies are $f_n = \frac{nv}{2L}$. For the second harmonic, $n = 2$, so $f_2 = \frac{2v}{2L} = \frac{v}{L} = \frac{340}{0.85} = 400\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Two sound waves with frequencies of $512\text{ Hz}$ and $518\text{ Hz}$ are played simultaneously. Calculate the beat frequency.
questions.explanation: The beat frequency is the absolute difference between the two frequencies: $f_{beat} = |518 - 512| = 6\text{ Hz}$.
